captions.text: Welcome to How To Cook That

I am Ann Reardon today we are making gingerbread
Christmas cookies.

We have a tradition in our family of making
a gingerbread house every Christmas.

I showed you how to make the houses last year
and had a lot of requests for gingerbread
cookies.

These are easy to make and lots of fun for
everyone to get involved in decorating.

To make your gingerbread dough place the butter
in a saucepan and melt it over a high heat.

All of the recipe quantities that you need
are on the website howtocookthat.net you will

also find a few different gingerbread house
designs there and a whole page of ginger bread

house ideas for you to check out. I'l put
a link to this recipe in the description just

below this video and that will link to all
the other pages.

Then measure out your sugar and your syrups,
I am using a mixture of glucose syrup and

golden syrup you can use some corn syrup,
maple syrup or even honey. Your choices will

change the flavour and colour of your cookie
dough a little bit but just substiute equal
quantities.

Stir that into the butter over the heat. Lift
up your spoon to see if your sugar is dissolved,

here you can still see the sugar crystals
still on the spoon so you need to keep stirring

it. Until it looks clear like this. Then take
it off the heat. Pour in the milk and stir
that through.

Add in the flour and sift in the ground ginger,
cloves, bicarb and cinnamon.

The reason i am sifting them is to make sure
we don't get any little lumps of spice in
one spot.

And then stir that through well, one of the
things I like about this recipe is you don't

need electric mixers with a dough hook like
lots of the ginger bread recipes do.

Spread some plastic wrap onto the bench and
then tip out your mixture. At this stage it

will be soft, sticky and gooey like this.
Wrap it up in the plastic wrap and leave it
at room temperature to cool.

Once it is cooled it will be the right consistency
to roll it out roll it out so roll it on some

baking paper. And then use some cookie cutters
to cut out your shapes.

And if you don't have any cutters you can
just print out shapes onto paper and use them

as a template and cut around it using a knife.
Then remove the excess dough, you can roll

that out later to make more cookies. or just
cut out squares using a ruler. This amount

of dough makes approximately 50 cookies it
depends on the shapes and sizes that you are
making.

Slide the paper onto a baking tray and place
them in the oven at 180 degrees for about

12 minutes. The time will vary depending on
the thickness you roll your dough and size

of your cookies. Once you can smell that gingerbread
smell wafting through the room they are probably
done.

If you are baking squares you'll need to take
it out of the oven and redo the cuts straight

away, the gingerbread is still quite soft
when it first comes out of the oven but will
firm up quickly as it cools.

To make your icing you will need icing sugar
or confectioners sugar, powdered egg white,

or if you can't get hold of that then meringue
or pavlova mix are both fine and some water.

Mix the egg white into the icing sugar then
add most of the water. If you are using powdered

egg white you will probably need nearly all
of the water but if you are using pavlova

mix you'll need a bit less. Then mix on medium
speed for about 5 minutes. Stop the mixer

and lift up the beaters if it is ready it
should have soft peaks that just bend over
slightly when you lift it up like this.

Split the mixture into as many bowls as you
want colours. And mix through some gel food

colouring. If you want pastel colours then
liquid colour would be fine but if you want

stronger colours you will need to use the
stronger gel colours.

I am using red, white and green for these
cookies. If you do want black then you will

need to mix in some cocoa powder and then
lots of black food coloring.

Scoop it into a piping bag or you can use
a ziplock bag. And cut a tiny bit off the

end so that you get a thin continuous stream
of icing when you squeeze the bag.

Draw an outline on you cookies, if you want
areas of different colours then draw a border

to seperate them out too. You can use the
same colour for the outline as you are going

to use for the middle section or you can use
a contrasting colour for the outline. And

of course you can use more than one colour
on each cookie to outline different ares as
well.

Once you have finished outlining let them
rest for about 5 minutes and then take some

of the icing mix some water in with it. Now
you want to add a few drops at a time. You

want it to be runny enough to meld down into
itself when you drizzle some from a spoon.

But you don't want it to be too watery. If
it is too watery once it has been on the cookie

it will soak in and it will leave it looking
strange.

Add some onto the cookie and then use a toothpick
to spread it out to the edges and into all

those little corners. Tap the cookie a few
times to smooth it our and release any air
bubbles.

If you want to you can of course add decorations
to the wet icing, on these green christmas
trees I ma using some mini m&m's.

Then you can repeat that for your other colours.
To avoid the colours running into each other

if you want you cookies perfect then let each
colour dry before adding the next one.

Once the icing is fairly dry you can go back
and pipe more details over the top.

I used the rest of my dough to make a nativity
scene which I will show you closer to christmas.

Thanks for your suggestions subscribe for
more desserts, chocolate and cake decorating

tutorials and add all your request in the
comments below. Have a great week, I'll see
you Friday.

title: Christmas Cookies Gingerbread Recipe HOW TO COOK THAT Ann Reardon sugar cookie frosting
